column6: Introduction to the scientific approach to understanding human behavior and mental processes such as emotions, perceptions and cognitions. Topics may include personality, social and environmental factors, biological aspects of behavior and the experience of emotion and psychological disorders.
A review of the data, concepts and theories of psychology that contribute to the understanding of child development from conception to age 14.

A review of theories, concepts and data that contribute to the understanding of human adjustment. Topics may include the following: personality, stress and coping, transitions from adolescence to adulthood, psychological disorders and psychotherapy.
Application of quantitative, statistical methods in psychological research. Descriptive and inferential methods (includes ANOVA, t-test and correlation).

Examination of areas of psychology upon which diversity issues have a bearing and focused study of psychological issues relevant to African-American, Asian- American, Hispanic/Latino American and American Indian groups.

Surveys major areas of forensic psychology, which focuses on the application of the science and profession of psychology to legal settings. Topics include roles and responsibilities of forensic psychologists, forensic assessment, psychological theories of criminal behavior, law enforcement psychology and eyewitness testimony.

Covers the mental processes that underline human thought and behavior, such as attention, memory, comprehension, reasoning, problem-solving and language. Considers established and current theoretical models, research methods and experimental results.
A review of the theories, concepts and data that contribute to our understanding of the physical, intellectual, educational, personality and social development of adolescents in contemporary society.

Processes and findings in social and personality development, with a focus on childhood and adolescence. Will include the examination of individual differences as well as developmental changes in social function and personality.

Covers the development of cognitive processes over the lifespan, especially during infancy and childhood. Important theoretical claims empirical results and research methods of relevant areas including memory are, critically evaluated.
Exploration of basic research and theory on the psychological consequences of aging and psychological factors that affect the behavior of older persons.

Factors that provide the energy and direction for behaviors, emotions and cognitive processes. Seeks to answer the question "why" concerning the things people do, feel and think. A survey approach is used to include both the traditional and newly emerging concepts in motivation.

Examination of basic principles of Pavlovian conditioning, instrumental conditioning, animal learning and memory processes, and animal cognition. Emphasis on major empirical phenomena derived from research with animals with reference to related psychological processes in humans.
Investigates how humans detect, organize and interpret information from the environment. Considers how both biological and psychological process create and influence our perception of the world.
Individual research open to qualified students. Repeatable for a total of 16 hours but see Arts and Sciences and psychology major/minor requirements for applicability limits.
The rationale, logic and procedures of scientific research in psychology with an emphasis on measurement, causal inference and research design.
Small sample theory, analysis of variance, linear regression and nonparametric statistics (e.g. Chi Square). This course may include qualitative analyses and computer based data analyses with SPSS.

Application of principles, facts and theories of psychology to people at work. Includes motivation and satisfaction at work, personnel selection and placement, training and development, performance appraisal, organizational development, quality of work life, ergonomics and consumer psychology.

Survey of the definitions as well as the biological, psychological and sociocultural causes of various psychological disorders. Illustrations of these disorders with cases. Overview of treatment approaches to these disorders may be included.
Introduction to psychometrics and test theory. Use and basic interpretation of intellectual and personality tests. Skills in using tests at a professional level not given.

Application of psychological principles and techniques to the problems of the individual. This course is designed to introduce the field of clinical psychology, including models of understanding abnormal behavior, treatment of individuals and ethics and professional issues.

Investigates psychological processes involved in language production, comprehension and development. Within each broad area emphasis is on theories, psychological experiments, key findings and the relationships between theory, method and data.

column2: DEVELOPMENT OF GENDER ROLE AND IDENTITY
column6: A life-span, developmental model is used to analyze the changes which occur with age in gender-related role performance and identity formation.

Course examines the historical context, influences and individuals instrumental in the development of psychology. Course organization is designed to compare and contrast systems, theories and fundamental issues with which psychologists have concerned themselves in past and contemporary stages of the science.
A review of the data, concepts and theories of psychology that contribute to the understanding of personality.

Covers the relationship between brain and behavior at the physiological, chemical and anatomical levels. Focuses on the association between the central nervous system and various processes and behaviors such as learning, emotions, neurological disorders and psychopathology.

column4: Must have junior standing and 9 credit hours in psychology and 3.0 GPA overall. Open to psychology majors only. Special approval required.
column6: Application of psychological knowledge and skills in applied settings. Allows academic credit for participation as an intern at approved internship sites including social service, non-profit agencies, government agencies and hospital settings. Course is repeated for credit.

In-depth examination of particular topics of current interest to faculty and students. Specialized areas of research theory or methodology may be covered. Specific topics announced. Repeated registration permitted.

Involves participation in empirical research, review of psychological literature and preparation of a paper or annotated bibliography. Repeatable for a total of 16 hours but see Arts and Sciences and psychology major/minor requirements for applicability limits.

Study of environmental/situational influences on our own and others' thoughts, behaviors and feelings-focus on topics such as aggression, attitudes and behaviors, conformity, helping, personal relationships and social cognition.

column2: LABORATORY EXPERIENCE IN PSYCHOLOGICAL RESEARCH: SOCIAL/CLINICAL
column4: 3.20 GPA and PSYC 11762 and PSYC 21621 and PSYC 31574.
column6: Intensive experience in the conduct, analysis and reporting of empirical research in social or clinical psychology. Specific content varies with instructor. Repeatable once with instructor, and departmental permission if topic is different.

column2: LABORATORY EXPERIENCE IN PSYCHOLOGICAL RESEARCH: COGNITIVE/LEARNING
column4: 3.20 GPA and PSYC 11762 and PSYC 21621 and PSYC 31574 and special approval.
column6: Intensive experience in the conduct, analysis and reporting of empirical research in cognitive psychology or human/animal learning. Specific content varies with instructor. Repeatable once with instructor and departmental permission if topic is different.

Role of psychological and social factors in health and illness, typically covering three general areas: (1) psychological factors affecting disease, (2) psychological and social consequences of illness and (3) psychotherapeutic interventions.
Writing-intensive course taken in conjunction with a 3-credit-hour, upper-division psychology course (except PSYC 31498, 41498, 41573, 41574 or 41993).
Seminar on various content areas of psychology. Specific topics announced.
Variable topic offered as need arises. Specific topics will be announced in the schedule of classes.

Course examines the historical context, influences and individuals instrumental in the development of psychology. Course organization is designed to compare and contrast systems theories and fundamental issues with which psychologists have concerned themselves in past and contemporary states of the science.
Variable topics offered as need arises to train in specific area of field. Specific topics will be announced in schedule of classes.
Introduction to psychopathology from a developmental perspective. Covers models of classification and specific disorders of childhood.
An examination of the etiology, symptomalogy and theoretical models of adult psychopathology.

column4: PSYC 6/70170 and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Introduction to the study of family interaction as it relates to the etiology and maintenance of psychopathology. Theory, methodology and research relevant to specific behavioral disorders will be covered.

column4: PSYC 6/70292 and PSYC 6/70792 and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Integration of assessment, psychopathology and psychotherapy coursework. Emphasis on learning how to conceptualize cases in general and from differing theoretical perspectives.

Introduction to psychological assessment as a process for solving important clinical problems. Theoretical methodological and research issues are emphasized. Students will also become familiar with major psychological tests.

column4: PSYC 6/70272 and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Examines psychodiagnosis within a context of "personality-as-a-coherent-whole." Emphasizes an ideographic approach with a theoretical framework, which organizes and gives meaning to observations.

column4: PSYC 6/70272 and PSYC 6/70292; and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: nterviewing, developmental and intellectual assessments personality evaluations behavioral assessments and assessment of special child populations. Emphasis on the rationale and integration of research relevant to appropriate use and interpretation.

column4: PSYC 6/70272 and PSYC 6/70292; and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Considers behavioral assessment from an empirical as well as an applied perspective. Intended for persons familiar with general assessment, psychopathology and psychotherapy issues.

column4: PSYC 6/70272 and PSYC 6/70292; graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Introduction to the conceptual foundations of neuropsychological assessment and practical knowledge in assessment procedures, methods of interpretation and differential diagnosis.

column4: Concurrent enrollment in PSYC 6/70272; and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Applied aspects of material presented in PSYC 6/70272. Emphasis on administering, scoring and interpreting major assessment tools.
Introduction to conceptualizations and findings in community psychology. Special emphasis on the application of community approaches in various settings.

column2: PROFESSIONAL ISSUES AND ETHICS IN CLINICAL PSYCHOLOGY
column6: Review of professional concerns in the field, including training, ethics, client rights, economics, legal issues, relationship to other professions and professional organization and policy.
Consideration of the interface of psychology and the law with focus on activities in which clinical psychologists are likely to participate in relation to the legal system.

Consideration of psychosocial influences on health status that are relevant to the clinician. Attention is given to interventions on both individual and community levels. Emphasis on approaches to prevention treatment and public policy.

column4: PSYC 6/70170 and PSYC 6/71260; and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Introduction to psychotherapy with special emphasis on psychodynamic and phenomenological approaches with theory, technique and major research findings considered.

column4: PSYC 6/70371 and PSYC 6/70792; and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Review of conceptual and empirical literature relating to psychotherapeutic treatment of various behavior disorders. A variety of theoretical orientations will be included.

column4: PSYC 6/70371 and PSYC 6/70792 and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Consideration of major theories, approaches and research in family therapy. Practical experience in conducting family therapy through supervision and discussion of ongoing cases.

column4: PSYC 6/70371 and PSYC 6/70792; and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Introduction to group psychotherapy with emphasis on theories, techniques and research findings.

column4: PSYC 6/70371 and PSYC 6/70292; and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Empirical and clinical aspects of cognitive and behavioral interventions. Intended for students familiar with basic psychotherapy assessment and psychopathology issues.

column4: PSYC 6/70371 and PSYC 6/70792; and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Consideration of various aspects of child psychotherapy, including general issues, traditional therapies, behavior and cognitive behavior therapies, and child therapy research. Emphasis on integration of theory, technique and research.

Advanced-level consideration of selected content areas in assessment, psychotherapy psycho pathology professional issues and community psychology. Specific topics will be announced in schedule of classes.
Information-processing approaches to human thought. Focus on processes used to transform store manipulate and retrieve sensory input. Topics include attention pattern recognition memory and language.
Examines psychological theory and research related to the psychology of adulthood through old age. Surveys current cognitive social developmental and clinical work on later life.

column4: PSYC 6/70292; concurrent enrollment in PSYC 6/70371; and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Basic training in applied aspects of psychotherapy. Through didactic and experiential methods students learn basic listening and communication skills that are then applied to specific techniques, situations and issues.
Advanced-level consideration of selected content areas in experimental psychology. Specific topics will be announced in schedule of classes.
Relationships between historical antecedents and the major contemporary systems and theories of psychology.
Introduction to basic conditioning processes. Emphasis on Pavlovian and instrumental learning phenomena particularly as these are exemplified in animal models of behavior.
Introduction to basic sensory and perceptual processes of vision and audition.
Thesis students must register for a total of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in a single semester distributed over several semesters if desired.
Consideration of major theoretical orientations including psychoanalysis, phenomenology and those stressing learning. Emphasis on principal concepts deals less with research methods and findings.
Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree requirements are met.
Neurophysiological, neurochemical and neuroanatomical factors in the control of cognitive processes motivation and behavior. Emphasis is on the broad coverage of major topics in the field.
Intensive pursuit of a subject matter beyond normal course coverage with possibility of associated research.
Research or individual investigation for master's level graduate students. Credits may be applied toward meeting degree requirements if department approves and if letter grade or "S" is given.
Neurophysiological, neurochemical and neuroanatomical factors in the control of cognitive processes motivation and behavior. Emphasis is on the broad coverage of major topics in the field.
Introduction to empirical research and theories on the psychological processes related to interpersonal and small group behavior.

column4: Graduate standing in psychology (PSYC) and special approval.
column6: Review of univariate statistics and an introduction to using bivariate and multivariate statistics. Part one of a two semester sequence on statistical analysis.

column4: PSYC 61651 or 71651 and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Multivariate statistics for classifying individuals and variables. Additional topics include power/effect size and handling missing data. Part two of a two-semester sequence on statistical analysis.

column4: PSYC 6/71651 and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Critical analysis of research design in psychology. Advanced topics in univariate and multivariate data analyses.
Consideration of research methodologies relevant to clinical psychology with emphasis on strengths and weaknesses of research designs and issues related to collection and evaluation of data.
Training and experience in college teaching. May be repeated to total of 6 hours.
Training and experience in college teaching. May be repeated to total of 6 hours.
Beginning practicum in psychological clinic involving selection, administration and evaluation of tests of ability and personality.

column4: PSYC 6/70192 and PSYC 6/70292 and PSYC 6/70792; and graduate standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Intensified experience in the diagnosis and treatment of specific disorders from the scientist-practitioner model.
Introduction to psychopathology from a developmental perspective. Covers models of classification and specific disorders of childhood.
An examination of the etiology, symptomalogy and theoretical models of adult psychopathology.

column4: PSYC 6/70170 and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Introduction to the study of family interaction as it relates to the etiology and maintenance of psychopathology. Theory, methodology and research relevant to specific behavioral disorders will be covered.

column4: PSYC 6/70292 and PSYC 6/70792; and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Integration of assessment, psychopathology and psychotherapy coursework. Emphasis on learning how to conceptualize cases in general and from differing theoretical perspectives.

Introduction to psychological assessment as a process for solving important clinical problems. Theoretical methodological and research issues are emphasized. Students will also become familiar with major psychological tests.

column4: PSYC 6/70272 and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Examines psychodiagnosis within a context of "personality-as-a-coherent-whole." Emphasizes an ideographic approach with a theoretical framework, which organizes and gives meaning to observations.

column4: PSYC 6/70272 and PSYC 6/70292; and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: nterviewing, developmental and intellectual assessments, personality evaluations, behavioral assessments, and assessment of special child populations. Emphasis on the rationale and integration of research relevant to appropriate use and interpretation.

column4: PSYC 6/70272 and PSYC 6/70292; and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Considers behavioral assessment from an empirical as well as an applied perspective. Intended for persons familiar with general assessment, psychopathology and psychotherapy issues.

column4: PSYC 6/70272 and PSYC 6/70292 and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Introduction to the conceptual foundations of neuropsychological assessment and practical knowledge in assessment procedures, methods of interpretation and differential diagnosis.

column4: Concurrent enrollment in PSYC 6/70272 and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Applied aspects of material presented in PSYC 6/70272. Emphasis on administering, scoring and interpreting major assessment tools.
Introduction to conceptualizations and findings in community psychology. Special emphasis on the application of community approaches in various settings.

column2: PROFESSIONAL ISSUES AND ETHICS IN CLINICAL PSYCHOLOGY
column6: Review of professional concerns in the field, including training, ethics, client rights, economics, legal issues, relationship to other professions and professional organization and policy.
Consideration of the interface of psychology and the law with focus on activities in which clinical psychologists are likely to participate in relation to the legal system.

Consideration of psychosocial influences on health status that are relevant to the clinician. Attention is given to interventions on both individual and community levels. Emphasis on approaches to prevention treatment and public policy.

column4: PSYC 6/70170 and PSYC 6/71260 and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Introduction to psychotherapy with special emphasis on psychodynamic and phenomenological approaches with theory, technique and major research findings considered.

column4: PSYC 6/70371 and PSYC 6/70792; and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Review of conceptual and empirical literature relating to psychotherapeutic treatment of various behavior disorders. A variety of theoretical orientations will be included.

column4: PSYC 6/70371 and PSYC 6/70792; and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Consideration of major theories, approaches and research in family therapy. Practical experience in conducting family therapy through supervision and discussion of ongoing cases.

column4: PSYC 6/70371 and PSYC 6/70792; and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Introduction to group psychotherapy with emphasis on theories, techniques and research findings.

column4: PSYC 6/70371 and PSYC 6/70292; and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Empirical and clinical aspects of cognitive and behavioral interventions. Intended for students familiar with basic psychotherapy assessment and psychopathology issues.

column4: PSYC 6/70371 and PSYC 6/70792; and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Consideration of various aspects of child psychotherapy, including general issues, traditional therapies, behavior and cognitive behavior therapies, and child therapy research. Emphasis on integration of theory technique and research.

Advanced-level consideration of selected content areas in assessment, psychotherapy, psychopathology, professional issues and community psychology. Specific topics will be announced in schedule of classes.
The effect of brain injury and anomalous neurological development on cognitive skills such as language, perception and memory are explored.
Study of relation between language and its speaker-listeners. Special emphasis placed on sentence and prose comprehension and language acquisition.

Information-processing approaches to human thought. Focus on processes used to transform, store, manipulate and retrieve sensory input. Topics include attention, pattern recognition, memory and language.

column4: PSYC 6/70453 and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Critical review of contemporary research and theory in memory and cognition.
Analysis of basic psychological processes involved in reading with emphasis on models of the skilled reader and of learning to read. Current research is surveyed.
Examination of theories and research concerning changes in memory, perception, thought and language over the life span.
Examines psychological theory and research related to the psychology of adulthood through old age. Surveys current cognitive, social, developmental and clinical work on later life.
Examination of theories and research in social development, with a focus on how personal relationships influence personality development.

column4: PSYC 6/70292; and concurrent enrollment in PSYC 6/70371; and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Basic training in applied aspects of psychotherapy. Through didactic and experiential methods students learn basic listening and communication skills that are then applied to specific techniques situations and issues.
Advanced-level consideration of selected content areas in experimental psychology. Specific topics will be announced in schedule of classes.
Relationships between historical antecedents and the major contemporary systems and theories of psychology.
Examination of basic phenomena and principles of memory, as exemplified by research with animals and humans. Consideration of behavioral and biological processes in memory functioning.

General principles of drug action with special attention to drugs used in the treatment of psychopathologies. Focus will be on neural mechanisms of action addiction and tolerance and drug interactions with learning and cognitive processes.

column4: PSYC 6/71350 and PSYC 6/70453; or PSYC 6/71054 and PSYC 6/71651; and special approval; and doctoral standing.
column6: General principles of connectionist modeling of memory, cognition and other psychological processes. Focus will be on the logic of connectionist models, plausibility of models and strategies for implementation of models.
Introduction to basic conditioning processes. Emphasis on Pavlovian and instrumental learning phenomena, particularly as these are exemplified in animal models of behavior.
Introduction to basic sensory and perceptual processes of vision and audition.
Consideration of major theoretical orientations including psychoanalysis, phenomenology and those stressing learning. Emphasis on principal concepts deals less with research methods and findings.
An introduction to non-neural aspects of psychobiology, with emphasis on psycho-endocrinology, psychoimmunology and the psychobiologic aspects of disease.
Neurophysiological, neurochemical and neuroanatomical factors in the control of cognitive processes motivation and behavior. Emphasis is on the broad coverage of major topics in the field.
Comprehensive literature survey and review prepared by graduate student in area of interest. May be repeated to total of 6 hours.

Explores both historical and current developments in cognitive social psychology including theory and research, social attention and memory, judgment and decision making, cognitive views of the self, and current debates regarding the relationship.
Examines concepts of disease and their implications for health. Emphasizes psychosocial stress in disease etiology and psychological factors influencing illness recovery.
Critical review of theories and empirical research on the use and abuse of alcohol.
Neurophysiological, neurochemical and neuroanatomical factors in the control of cognitive processes motivation and behavior. Emphasis is on the broad coverage of major topics in the field.
Introduction to empirical research and theories on the psychological processes related to interpersonal and small group behavior.

column4: Doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC) and special approval.
column6: Review of univariate statistics and an introduction to using bivariate and multivariate statistics. Part one of a two semester sequence on statistical analysis.

column4: PSYC 61651 or 71651 and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Multivariate statistics for classifying individuals and variables. Additional topics include power/effect size and handling missing data. Part two of a two semester sequence on statistical analysis.

column4: PSYC 6/71654 and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Survey of major types of factor analytic methods employed in psychology.

column2: FIELD RESEARCH METHODS AND PROGRAM EVALUATION
column6: Focus is on research designs used in field research and on threats to valid causal inference. Measurement and analytical issues are also examined.

column4: PSYC 6/71651 and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Critical analysis of research design in psychology. Advanced topics in univariate and multivariate data analyses.
Consideration of research methodologies relevant to clinical psychology with emphasis on strengths and weaknesses of research designs and issues related to collection and evaluation of data.

column4: PSYC 6/71651 and PSYC 6/71654; and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Programming applications in psychology.
Training and experience in college teaching. May be repeated to total of 6 hours.
Training and experience in college teaching. May be repeated to total of 6 hours.
Students increase their multicultural awareness and develop competencies necessary for clinical work with members of ethnic minority groups.
Beginning practicum in psychological clinic involving selection, administration and evaluation of tests of ability and personality.

column4: PSYC 61651 or PSYC 71651; and PSYC 61654 or PSYC 71654; and doctoral standing.
column6: Intended to cover two major multivariate statistical techniques in psychology: structural equation modeling (SEM) and hierarchical linear modeling (HLM).

column4: PSYC 6/70192 and PSYC 6/70292 and PSYC 6/70792; and doctoral standing in psychology (PSYC).
column6: Intensified experience in the diagnosis and treatment of specific disorders from the scientist-practitioner model.
Seminar devoted to detailed study of various topics in field of clinical psychology. Specific topics will be announced in schedule of classes.
Seminar on current research in cognitive psychology. Specific topics will be announced in schedule of classes.

column2: SEMINAR IN CHILD AND DEVELOPMENTAL PSYCHOLOGY
column6: Seminar on current research in child and developmental psychology. Specific topics will be announced in schedule of classes.
Seminar on current research in learning and biopsychology. Specific topics will be announced in the schedule of classes.

Doctoral dissertation, for which registration in at least two semesters is required the first of which will be semester in which dissertation work is begun and continuing until the completion of 30 hours.
Continuing registration required of doctoral students who have completed the initial 30 hours of dissertation and continuing until all degree requirements are met.
Research or individual investigation for doctoral students. Credits may be applied toward degree if department approves.

column2: SEMINAR IN PERSONALITY AND SOCIAL PSYCHOLOGY
column6: Seminar on current research in areas of social psychology. Specific topics will be announced in schedule of classes.
Seminar on applications of quantitative methods within various content areas of psychology. Specific topics will be announced in schedule of classes.
